dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Goldman Sachs is expecting a one percent chance of a non-FDA-approved vaccine treating five million Americans by the next decade.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goldman believes theres a 48% chance that there will be enough doses of an FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine to treat 25 million Americans by the second or third quarters, the most likely time lines, followed closely by 42% odds that this will happen by the first quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're also saying there's a ninety-nine percent chance it happens by the fourth quarter this year. That's, uh, pretty specific.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then Glenmede's out here with this wild prediction about earnings hitting new lows in the first half of 2021, which they say aligns with estimates for an alien invasion. I mean, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then Glenmede's out here with this wild prediction about earnings hitting new lows in the first half of twenty twenty one, which they say aligns with estimates for an alien invasion. I mean, what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Like, are we supposed to take that seriously? It feels like they're just throwing stuff out there to get attention.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Like, are we supposed to take that seriously? It feels like they're just throwing stuff out there to get attention.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then LPL Financial thinks we might be a century away from destabilized earnings. A century! That's… bleak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then L P L Financial thinks we might be a century away from destabilized earnings. A century! That's... bleak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a Monday note to clients, LPL Financial had similar hopes, saying, The combination of efficiencies gained during the recession, the strong performance of the winners and the tremendous progress in Covid-19 treatment and vaccine development, all suggest we may be only a year away from reaching normalized earnings, though we fully recognize the risk that time line may end up being too aggressive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, ExxonMobil's reporting Friday, and their shares are down ninety-nine percent this year alone. How is that even possible?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, ExxonMobil's reporting Friday, and their shares are down ninety-nine percent this year alone. How is that even possible?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I know, but energy ETFs are up ninety percent for the year. It's such a weird disconnect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, but energy ETFs are up ninety percent for the year. It's such a weird disconnect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The worst-performing sectors are energy (down 36%) and financials (down 16%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And JPMorgan, which is supposedly the worst-performing bank, has seen shares soar nearly a hundred and fifty percent. Nothing makes sense anymore.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And JPMorgan, which is supposedly the worst-performing bank, has seen shares soar nearly a hundred and fifty percent. Nothing makes sense anymore.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: JPMorgan, the nations biggest bank, led by Jamie Dimon, reports tomorrow and has seen shares plummet nearly 28% this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Goldman's only expecting a two percent increase in third-quarter earnings per share for the S&P 500, after that fifty percent surge last quarter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Goldman's only expecting a two percent increase in third-quarter earnings per share for the S&P five hundred, after that fifty percent surge last quarter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats how much Goldman said it expects third-quarter earnings per share will fall among S&P 500 firms, compared to a 32% drop in the second quarter and a 15% fall in the first.

dialogue_turns.text: Which, honestly, sounds almost conservative compared to some of these other projections.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, honestly, sounds almost conservative compared to some of these other projections.

artist_script:
HostA: Goldman Sachs is expecting a one percent chance of a non-FDA-approved vaccine treating five million Americans by the next decade.
HostB: Yeah, and they’re also saying there’s a ninety-nine percent chance it happens by the fourth quarter this year. That’s, uh, pretty specific.
HostA: But then Glenmede’s out here with this wild prediction about earnings hitting new lows in the first half of 2021, which they say aligns with estimates for an alien invasion. I mean, what?
HostB: Right? Like, are we supposed to take that seriously? It feels like they’re just throwing stuff out there to get attention.
HostA: And then LPL Financial thinks we might be a century away from destabilized earnings. A century! That’s… bleak.
HostB: Meanwhile, ExxonMobil’s reporting Friday, and their shares are down ninety-nine percent this year alone. How is that even possible?
HostA: I know, but energy ETFs are up ninety percent for the year. It’s such a weird disconnect.
HostB: And JPMorgan, which is supposedly the worst-performing bank, has seen shares soar nearly a hundred and fifty percent. Nothing makes sense anymore.
HostA: Goldman’s only expecting a two percent increase in third-quarter earnings per share for the S&P 500, after that fifty percent surge last quarter.
HostB: Which, honestly, sounds almost conservative compared to some of these other projections.
HostA: And then you’ve got Southwest Airlines, Tesla, all reporting after the bell on Friday. It’s gonna be a packed day.
HostB: For sure. Plus, Bank of America and Wells Fargo on Monday. If JPMorgan hints at economic collapse, Marc Chaikin thinks it could actually help bank stocks.
HostA: Help? How does that work?
HostB: Something about it driving market momentum, I guess? Honestly, at this point, alien invasions sound more plausible.
